Days later, defendants issued a RIF affecting approximately 90% of the agency's workforce. The plaintiffs asked the district court to halt this RIF, and the D.C. Circuit lifted its partial stay on April 28, 2025, reinstating the full injunction. The D.C. Circuit ultimately dismissed the defendants' appeal on May 12, 2025, affirming the district court's preliminary injunction.
results.PN-NY-0014: Ligon v. City of New York is a federal class action lawsuit challenging the New York City Police Department's (NYPD) practice of making unconstitutional stops, frisks, and arrests on suspicion of trespass outside buildings enrolled in the Trespass Affidavit Program (TAP), a program that allows NYPD officers to patrol inside and around private residential apartment buildings. The case was filed on March 28, 2012, by Black and Latino residents of New York City who alleged they and their minor children were unlawfully stopped, questioned, frisked, and/or arrested in or around their homes or family members' homes. The plaintiffs sought relief under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, alleging violations of the Fourth Amendment (unreasonable search and seizure) and the Fourteenth Amendment (equal protection). The court granted a preliminary injunction on January 8, 2013, finding that the plaintiffs had shown a "clear likelihood of proving" that the City, by its deliberate indifference, had a policy of conducting unconstitutional trespass stops outside TAP buildings in the Bronx. The court ordered the NYPD to cease performing trespass stops outside TAP buildings without reasonable suspicion of trespass. The case was related to Floyd v. City of New York, which challenged the NYPD's broader stop-and-frisk practices, and Davis v. City of New York, which challenged trespass enforcement in public housing. The court's Remedies Opinion, issued on August 12, 2013, ordered specific reforms to the NYPD's policies, training, supervision, auditing, and monitoring procedures. The court appointed Peter L. Zimroth as an independent monitor to oversee implementation of the reforms. The parties eventually reached a settlement agreement on July 19, 2017, which was approved by the court. The settlement required the NYPD to implement specific policy changes regarding stops, frisks, and trespass enforcement in TAP buildings, as well as to revise training materials, establish improved auditing procedures, and comply with the terms of the court's Remedies Opinion. The settlement also provided for court-ordered monitoring for a period of three years (with the possibility of extension) to ensure compliance with the settlement terms. The monitor's reports have documented ongoing efforts to ensure NYPD officers comply with the court-ordered reforms, including changes to policies, training, supervision, and auditing procedures.
results.PB-CT-0007: This case challenges Section 3 of the Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA), which defines "marriage" for federal purposes as "only a legal union between one man and one woman as husband and wife" and "spouse" as "a person of the opposite sex who is a husband or a wife." Plaintiffs, six same-sex couples legally married under the laws of Connecticut, Vermont, and New Hampshire, filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Connecticut, alleging that DOMA violates the Fifth Amendment's Equal Protection Clause by denying them federal benefits available to opposite-sex married couples. The plaintiffs suffered concrete harms: Joanne Pedersen was denied health insurance coverage for her spouse under the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program; Gerald V. Passaro II was denied Social Security survivor benefits and a qualified preretirement survivor annuity; Lynda DeForge was denied family medical leave to care for her spouse; Janet Geller and Joanne Marquis were denied health insurance benefits under the New Hampshire Retirement System; and Suzanne Artis and Geraldine Artis, Bradley Kleinerman and James Gehre, and Damon Savoy and John Weiss were denied the ability to file federal income tax returns as married couples. The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and denied the government's motion to dismiss, holding that DOMA violates the Fifth Amendment's Equal Protection Clause. The court determined that classifications based on sexual orientation warrant heightened scrutiny and, even under rational basis review, DOMA fails constitutional muster. The government and the Bipartisan Legal Advisory Group of the U.S. House of Representatives appealed the district court's judgment to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, while the plaintiffs petitioned for a writ of certiorari before judgment in the Supreme Court.
results.PC-AL-0034: The United States filed a civil rights complaint against the State of Alabama and the Alabama Department of Corrections (ADOC) on May 28, 2015, under the Civil Rights of Institutionalized Persons Act (CRIPA), 42 U.S.C. § 1997. The complaint alleged that ADOC violated the Eighth Amendment by failing to protect women prisoners at Tutwiler Prison for Women from sexual abuse and sexual harassment, based on a January 17, 2014 investigation by the U.S. Department of Justice that documented a history of staff sexual abuse and a toxic sexualized environment. The parties entered into a settlement agreement on May 28, 2015, which was approved by the court on June 18, 2015. The agreement required ADOC and Tutwiler to implement comprehensive reforms including developing gender-responsive policies, implementing a staffing plan, providing specialized staff training, improving inmate education about sexual abuse and harassment, establishing a risk assessment system, and addressing architectural issues related to privacy. The agreement established a monitoring process with an independent monitor to evaluate compliance, requiring biannual compliance reports. The monitor's eighth compliance report, filed on August 27, 2019, indicated that Tutwiler and ADOC had achieved "substantial compliance" with 41 sections of the agreement and "partial compliance" with 2 sections. The monitor noted ongoing challenges primarily related to staffing levels, with only 44% of correctional officer positions filled, though significant progress had been made in implementing gender-responsive policies, classification systems, programming, and staff training. The settlement requires continued monitoring until full compliance is achieved.
results.ED-MI-0001: In November 2006, Michigan voters approved Proposal 2, an amendment to the Michigan Constitution that prohibited public universities from considering race in admissions decisions. The Coalition to Defend Affirmative Action, Integration and Immigrant Rights and Fight for Equality By Any Means Necessary (BAMN), along with students, faculty, and other organizations, filed a federal lawsuit challenging the amendment as violating the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment. The plaintiffs argued that Proposal 2 violated the Equal Protection Clause by restructuring Michigan's political process to place an undue burden on racial minorities seeking to change admissions policies that benefit them, and by making it more difficult for minorities to achieve beneficial legislation compared to other groups. The district court granted summary judgment for the state, finding Proposal 2 constitutional. The Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals reversed, holding that Proposal 2 violated the Equal Protection Clause by impermissibly restructuring the political process. The Supreme Court of the United States reversed the Sixth Circuit's decision, holding that Michigan's voters had the right to determine that race-based preferences in university admissions should be ended, and that the Equal Protection Clause does not prohibit a state from banning the consideration of race in admissions decisions. The Supreme Court emphasized that the case was not about whether race-conscious admissions policies are constitutionally permissible, but rather about whether Michigan voters could choose to prohibit such policies. The Court found that Proposal 2 did not violate the Equal Protection Clause because it did not inflict a specific injury on racial minorities, as was present in cases like Hunter v. Erickson and Washington v. Seattle School District, but rather involved a decision by voters to change the policy regarding race-conscious admissions. The Supreme Court's decision effectively upheld Michigan's constitutional amendment banning affirmative action in public university admissions.
results.DR-CA-0033: Maurizio Antoninetti, a wheelchair user, filed a lawsuit against Chipotle Mexican Grill, Inc. in 2005, alleging that Chipotle's restaurants violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and California Disabled Persons Act by denying him equal access to the "Chipotle experience." Antoninetti claimed the 44-inch high wall in front of food preparation counters blocked his view of food ingredients and the preparation process, preventing him from seeing the same visual elements available to standing customers. Chipotle initially relied on an unwritten policy of providing accommodations (such as showing food samples in cups or displaying ingredients at the cashier counter), which the district court initially found inadequate, but later adopted a written "Customers with Disabilities Policy" that the district court ruled provided "equivalent facilitation." The district court denied Antoninetti's request for injunctive relief but awarded him $5,000 in statutory damages for five "bona fide" visits to Chipotle's restaurants before the written policy was implemented. On appeal, the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals reversed the district court, holding that Chipotle's written policy did not constitute "equivalent facilitation" under ADA Accessibility Guidelines (ADAAG) Section 2.2, as it did not involve "other designs and technologies" that would provide "substantially equivalent or greater access." The court found that Chipotle's wall design violated the ADA because it prevented wheelchair users from having the same visual experience of food preparation available to standing customers. The court also vacated the $5,000 damages award and remanded for further proceedings on damages. After remand, the district court entered judgment against Chipotle for violation of the ADA, awarded Antoninetti $5,000 in statutory damages for the five "bona fide" visits, and denied injunctive relief (which was rendered moot by Antoninetti's death in 2011). The district court also awarded Antoninetti $545,079.05 in attorney's fees, which the Ninth Circuit later reviewed and adjusted. The case established that public accommodations cannot rely on policies of providing methods of accommodation to avoid architectural compliance with ADA standards when the visual elements of the experience are integral to the service being provided.
results.CJ-FL-0009: On November 6, 2018, Florida voters overwhelmingly approved Amendment 4 to the state constitution, which automatically restored voting rights to most felons upon completion of all terms of their sentences, including parole or probation. The amendment passed with 64.55% of the vote, reflecting the will of the people to expand voting rights to approximately 1.4 million individuals. Shortly after the amendment took effect, the Florida Legislature enacted Senate Bill 7066 (SB 7066), which interpreted "completion of all terms of sentence" to include payment of all legal financial obligations (LFOs) such as fines, fees, and restitution imposed as part of a criminal sentence. The plaintiffs, 17 individuals with felony convictions who had completed all terms of their sentences but were unable to pay outstanding LFOs, filed a lawsuit challenging SB 7066 as unconstitutional. They asserted that the requirement to pay LFOs as a condition of voting violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment as applied to indigent felons, the Twenty-Fourth Amendment (which prohibits poll taxes), and the Due Process Clause. The district court granted a preliminary injunction in October 2019, ruling that Florida could not deny the right to vote based solely on inability to pay LFOs. The Eleventh Circuit affirmed this ruling in Jones v. Governor of Florida, 950 F.3d 795 (11th Cir. 2020), applying heightened scrutiny to the pay-to-vote requirement as applied to indigent felons. After a bench trial, the district court issued a permanent injunction on May 24, 2020, declaring that SB 7066 violated the Equal Protection Clause as applied to felons who could not pay their LFOs, and also violated the Twenty-Fourth Amendment. The court also ruled that the law was void for vagueness and denied due process. The Eleventh Circuit affirmed the district court's permanent injunction on September 11, 2020, rejecting the State's argument that only rational basis review applied and finding that the pay-to-vote requirement was unconstitutional as applied to indigent felons. The court held that Florida's reenfranchisement scheme did not violate the Constitution and vacated the district court's injunction. The State had argued that the law was constitutional because it promoted the legitimate state interest of ensuring that felons who regained voting rights had fully satisfied their sentences, but the court found that the law's implementation created administrative chaos that denied due process to many felons who could not determine whether they owed LFOs or how much they needed to pay. The court also rejected the argument that LFOs were taxes prohibited by the Twenty-Fourth Amendment, finding that the fees and costs were part of the criminal sentence and thus not taxes.
results.CW-CA-0005: Katie A. v. Bonta is a class action lawsuit filed in 2002 on behalf of children in California foster care or at imminent risk of foster care placement who have mental health needs. The plaintiffs, represented by ACLU and other public interest law firms, alleged that the state of California and Los Angeles County violated the Medicaid Act's Early and Periodic Screening, Diagnostic and Treatment (EPSDT) provisions by failing to provide necessary mental health services, including wraparound services and therapeutic foster care (TFC). The case was certified as a class action for children who (a) are in foster care or at imminent risk of foster care placement; (b) have a mental illness or condition that has been documented or would have been documented; and (c) need individualized mental health services. The district court initially granted a preliminary injunction requiring the state to provide wraparound services and TFC as "packages" to eligible children, but the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals reversed this decision in 2007, holding that the district court misapplied the law by requiring the state to provide "wraparound" and "TFC" as distinct services rather than determining whether the state was providing the necessary components of these services. After the Ninth Circuit's ruling, the parties negotiated a settlement agreement approved by the court on July 16, 2003 for Los Angeles County defendants, and later for the state defendants, which required the state to develop and implement a plan to provide wraparound services and TFC to eligible children. The settlement agreement required the state to develop a Medi-Cal Specialty Mental Health documentation manual, establish a Shared Management Structure between state agencies, and implement a Core Practice Model for mental health services. A Special Master was appointed to monitor compliance with the settlement. The case has been ongoing for over 20 years with multiple reports and updates from the Special Master regarding the state's implementation of the settlement. The case is now closed with the court retaining jurisdiction for a specific period to ensure compliance with the settlement agreement.
results.PC-VA-0022: Eric J. DePaola, a Virginia inmate sentenced to 38 years in prison in 2004 for crimes including malicious wounding, use of a firearm, and abduction, was placed in administrative segregation (solitary confinement) at Red Onion State Prison following a 2009 incident in which he stabbed a prison guard. The Virginia Department of Corrections (VDOC) placed DePaola in the Intensive Management (IM) classification under VDOC Operating Procedure 830.A (OP 830.A), which governs the classification and management of segregation inmates. Unlike Special Management (SM) inmates who can participate in a step-down program to eventually return to the general population, IM inmates are not eligible for this program and remain in segregation indefinitely. DePaola has been confined in segregation for approximately eight years (from 2009 to 2017), during which time he has received few disciplinary infractions—only two "100 series" charges (for tampering with a sink lever and alleged possession of a sharpened instrument) and a few minor "200 series" charges related to possession of contraband. The Institutional Classification Authority (ICA) reviews, which occur every 90 days, have not provided meaningful review of DePaola's eligibility for return to general population, as they merely determine his privilege level within segregation rather than his fitness for return to the general population. In December 2014, DePaola filed a pro se civil rights action under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 against VDOC and various officials, alleging that VDOC's classification procedures violated his procedural due process rights under the Fourteenth Amendment and that the conditions of his prolonged solitary confinement violated the Eighth Amendment's prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment. The district court denied DePaola's motion for appointment of counsel and his motion to certify the case as a class action. After amending his complaint, DePaola opposed the defendants' motion for summary judgment, arguing that his eight years in solitary confinement without meaningful opportunity for return to general population violated constitutional protections. The district court granted summary judgment to the defendants on all claims, finding that DePaola's solitary confinement did not implicate a protected liberty interest and that his conditions of confinement did not constitute cruel and unusual punishment. DePaola appealed the district court's decision to the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals, which is now considering whether the district court erred in granting summary judgment without allowing for meaningful discovery.
results.CJ-MD-0001: Vernon Evans, a death row inmate in Maryland, filed a federal lawsuit challenging the state's lethal injection protocol under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, alleging it violated the Eighth Amendment by creating an unnecessary risk of pain during execution. The protocol used a three-drug cocktail: sodium pentothal (an anesthetic), pancuronium bromide (a paralytic), and potassium chloride (a heart-stopping agent). Evans argued the protocol's design, including the absence of properly trained personnel to monitor anesthesia, the use of a pressure infusion bag, and the failure to plan for potential IV access issues (particularly given Evans's history of intravenous drug use), created a substantial risk of unnecessary pain. The case arose after Evans received a warrant of execution setting his execution for February 2006. Evans also challenged the protocol's adoption as a "regulation" under Maryland's Administrative Procedure Act (APA), arguing the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services failed to follow required rulemaking procedures. The district court denied Evans's motion for a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction, finding he had not shown a likelihood of success on the merits. The Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals dismissed Evans's appeal, but the case was later remanded. The district court ultimately held that while the protocol did not violate the Eighth Amendment (as previously determined in similar cases), the execution protocol did constitute a "regulation" under the APA that had not been properly adopted. The court ordered the state to either adopt the protocol in compliance with the APA or seek legislative exemption from the requirement, effectively halting any execution using the current protocol until the state complied with the APA. The court's ruling established that Maryland's execution protocol needed formal adoption under the state's administrative procedures before it could be used in executions.
results.CW-DC-0001:
LaShawn A. v. District of Columbia is a landmark class action lawsuit filed on June 20, 1989, on behalf of children in the District of Columbia's foster care system and children known to the District's Department of Human Services (DHS) due to reported abuse or neglect. Represented by the ACLU and Children's Rights, the plaintiffs alleged that the District's child welfare system violated federal statutes, including the Adoption Assistance and Child Welfare Act and the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act, as well as the Fifth Amendment's due process protections under the Constitution. After a two-week trial in February 1991, the District Court found the District in violation of these rights, concluding that the child welfare system was operating in "widespread and systematic deficiencies" that caused emotional and physical harm to children. The court determined that the District had failed to comply with reasonable professional standards in almost every area of its child welfare system, with children remaining in foster care for years without permanent placement, investigations of abuse reports being delayed or inadequate, and foster care placements often inappropriate for the children's needs.

The court entered a Remedial Order in August 1991, which was later modified to be based solely on District law after the D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals held that District law provided an independent basis for the court's judgment. The Modified Final Order, entered January 27, 1994, established specific requirements for the District to reform its child welfare system. When the District failed to comply with these requirements, the court appointed a receiver in 1995 to oversee the child welfare system. Over the next 25 years, the court approved multiple implementation plans, with the Center for the Study of Social Policy serving as the court-appointed monitor to track the District's progress.

The case continued through numerous appeals and modifications to the implementation plans as the District made incremental improvements but repeatedly failed to meet the required standards. The District's compliance with the court's orders was closely monitored, with the court addressing issues such as timely investigations of abuse reports, appropriate foster care placements, and the provision of essential services to children. After more than 30 years of court supervision, the parties reached agreement on an Exit and Sustainability Plan in 2019, which the court approved. This plan marked the end of the court's supervision of the District's child welfare system, as the District had achieved and maintained compliance with the required standards for several years. The case is notable for being one of the longest-running child welfare reform cases in U.S. history, demonstrating the complexity of systemic reform and the court's role in ensuring accountability for vulnerable children.
